adjective.description: Of or at a fairly low temperature.
Showing no friendliness toward a person or enthusiasm for an idea or project.
examples: he gave a cool reception to the suggestion for a research center
I always wore sunglasses to look cool

adjective.description: Used to emphasize a specified quantity or amount, especially of money.
examples: a cool $15,000 to buy the franchise
the cool of the night air
he recovered his cool and then started laughing at us

noun.description: The quality of being fashionably attractive or impressive.
examples: all the cool of high fashion

verb.description: Become or cause to become less hot.
examples: we dived into the river to cool off
cool the pastry for five minutes
his feelings for her took a long time to cool

phrases: She had to stay calm and keep her cool before the match.
William somehow managed to keep his cool and retain control of their car.
There are two kinds: people who freak out, and people who keep their cool.
Despite the fact that he was vastly outnumbered John never lost his cool, stayed calm and came away with a deserved victory.
We'll teach you how to keep your cool and stay calm in tight situations.
origin: Old English cōl (noun), cōlian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch koel, also to cold.
